title: Apprentice star says she quit due to 'emotional abuse' after show bosses sabotaged tasks

A former Apprentice star has made some shocking claims about the way candidates are treated on the show.

Alexsandra King spoke out during an inquest into the way reality TV contestants.

She said that the hopefuls on The Apprentice are intentionally not fed properly and barely have time to sleep.

She also claimed the producers deliberately sabotage the tasks to make things harder for the candidates.

The terrible treatment during filming drove Aleksandra, 41, to quit the show in 2016.

(Image: BBC/Boundless)

The Daily Star reported on a letter Aleksandra wrote to to MPs on the the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport committee’s inquiry.

They are investigating reality TV following the death of construction worker Steve Dymond, 63, who failed a lie detector test on The Jeremy Kyle Show and reportedly struggled to deal with the fallout from the show.

Aleksandra spoke about a task where her team were selling candy, and they checked on their stock before leaving it with producers.

She said: “Upon returning, we were shocked to see that not only was there stock missing but that our candy sticks were also cracked.

“I was conscious this would damage my reputation and addressed it with production at the time stating that I know what they did.”

She also said that the candidates have irregular meals and barely get any sleep with long hours and early wakeup calls.

This, she claims, "ensures candidates are physically and mentally weakened".

(Image: BBC/Boundless)

Aleksandra also slammed producers for “not allowing candidates to speak even to each other for many hours during and after tasks so that feelings and emotions are stored for the camera.”

She added: “By the time I made the decision to leave the show I was at the end of my line.

“I am happy to support this committee in ensuring that future candidates do not become victims of emotional abuse at the expense of ‘entertainment’.”

(Image: BBC)

Rebecca Jeffrey, who appeared on the show in the same year as Aleksandra, has also spoken of the impact it's had on her mental health.

“Losing your autonomy for up to six weeks during which you have very limited contact with your support network, friends and family, can make resettling back into your normal life immediately afterwards very strange", she said.

Personally I found that around three months after the ‘high’ of The Apprentice I was still trying to deal with the impact.”

MirrorOnline has reached out to the BBC's representatives for comment.
description: Alexsandra King has made the shocking claim that Apprentice candidates are "emotionally abused" by starvation, lack of sleep, and producers sabotaging tasks
